Friday, April 27, 2007























Study says obese workers costing employers
Overweight workers cost their bosses more in injury claims than their lean colleagues, suggests a study that found the heaviest employees had twice the rate of workers' compensation claims as their fit co-workers. Obesity experts said they hope the study will convince employers to invest in programs to help fight obesity. 
FULL STORY




















Study sees link between diabetes and depression
Elderly people who are depressed are more likely to become diabetic than those who are not, according to a study that suggests depression may play a role in causing the most common form of diabetes.
FULL STORY






Nutrition standards urged for foods sold in school
The Institute of Medicine proposed standards for foods sold in schools that would encourage youngsters to eat more fruits, vegetables and whole grains and to avoid added sugars, salt and saturated fats.
FULL STORY






Executed in U.S. may be awake as they suffocate
Lethal-injection drugs sometimes fail to work as planned, causing slow and painful deaths that probably violate constitutional bans on cruel and unusual punishment, a review concludes.
FULL STORY






Study discounts abortion-breast cancer link
A Harvard study supports earlier findings that having an abortion doesn't increase a woman's risk of getting breast cancer. It found that childbearing before 35 cuts breast cancer risk; breast-feeding also helps.
